title: Lumia Icon 929 Car Mount with Nokia Charging Plate

description.text: This is a car mount for the Lumia Icon and it has a slot for the Nokia Wireless charging plate. The icon fits in pretty perfectly, tight enough to hold but loose enough to slide in and out with no resistance. You will need to figure out your own mounting solution to actually attach it in the car. I personally glued mine to an old garmin suction mount. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/2CK8owVqSQu
I printed this on a Makerbot Replicator 2 at low settings with a 2% infill and no raft or support.

author: okiedokieiguess

description.text: This is for my green singer finches. Their old bowl has broken, and they're getting broody. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/g98v23t2pe3

I recommend measuring your bar spacing and making sure the hooks match your cage if you make this. It should be easy to copy and modify on TinkerCAD- the hanging supports were the last thing I added so they're not in the group with the bowl itself.
I believe this will print without support- that's the goal.  I haven't tried it yet, though. My printer is down at the moment.
Up to v.3 of the next bowl.  Hopefully this one will work.
This polar bear prints butt up. Also, the claws are very delicate.

This beautiful tiara should be worn with flare.

The T MAX is a derivative of the MendelMax.
It main features:
  • Taller print height by placing the side columns vertical, and widen the space between the the top horizontal beams to allow the extruder assemble to protruded pass the beams.
  • With the side columns vertical and closer toward the center of the printer, one has better accessibility to the print bed and extruder.
  • More height under the bed to accommodate the mounting of power supply, controller, and control panels.
    • The T MAX uses all the same major components as the MendelMax. If you have a MendelMax, it can be easily converted to a T MAX; or assemble a T MAX from a MendelMax extrusion and hardware kit.
    The T MAX is design to use low maintenance Igus pillow block bearings, a RAMPS 1.4 controller, and a common eBay 12VDC, 30A power supply. Maximum print size is approximately X 210mm, Y 210mm and Z 210mm. T MAX LCD & SD Control Panel: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29903
    T MAX Spool Holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29883

See illustrations for locations of parts. Assemble using MendelMax components and fasteners. Special instructions:
  • Drill two 6mm holes (140mm apart, symmetrically from center) on the top two horizontal aluminum extrusions of the base.
  • Fasten the bottom of the vertical extrusions using 40mm long, 5mm bolts and 15mm OD washers (3/16 X 1-1/2 stove bolts will also work). Don't forget to tap the holes to suit the bolts used.
  • Run the bolts through the whole cross-section of the horizontal extrusions. This will add greater strength to the assembly.
    • The higher Z axis will require a pair of longer thread rods, 400mm long.

comments.text: I like the design but I don't think that the z threaded rods should be confined in 3 points: motor shaft, end and just above the coupler. Unless you have super straight threaded rods, you'll have z wobble. Its best to take out the additional constraints.
comments.author: brnrd

comments.text:
Â Each Z thread rod does indeed only have two restrain points, one 608 bearing at top, and the Z motor flex coupling.
Sorry about the confusion with the naming of one of the parts: Z THREAD ROD BEARING MOUNT BOTTOM. This part has only a pass through hole for the thread rod and does not mount a bearing. The part came from another printer design I was working on.

title: Spool Extender Clip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have my spool mounted flat, and had some trouble with the filament slipping off the spool.  I used binder clips to extend the bottom part of the spool, and while that solved one problem, it created others (like the filament getting caught on the binder clip).  
This spool clip keeps the filament from slipping off the spool, and won't inadvertently catch on the filament while the spool is turning.  
It's fully customizable.  See the 4th photo if you're having trouble figuring out what parameter means what.
Print 3 or 4 clips and attach to the bottom part of your spool.

description.text: made to fix a moebius cam on top of a plane (or whatever you want to fix it on it), easily click in place, firmly hold, and weightless.

I printed it in abs, 0.4wide, 0.3 high . i added a bit of acetone with a brush to perfect the layer cohesion.
there is a hole to fix it with the plane screw.
Iadded the skp file for the people who want to adapt it. the sides are bended inward to give enough spring force to hold the cam firmly . you can easily add some safety with a rubber band around the top of the support

title: Spool Holder for Prusa Mendel by SJP

description.text:
I designed a spool holder based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:22292
This is a two piece design designed to fit in a small print bed. Fits on standard Prusa Mendel. Pieces are 10 mm thick. Designed to hold 5LB spools. Print Dimensions:
Full Plate V1.1: 185 mm x 117 mm
Base: 135 x 75mm
Extension Arm: 147 mm x 100 mm
Cross beam: 185mm x 15mm Version History:
V1.0 First print designed, Holds 6mm or 1/4" rod (Pictured and uploaded.)
V1.1 Modified spool bar holder to incorporate 8mm rod. (Uploaded) This is my first part designed, printed and uploaded. Any comments and suggestions is appreciated.

Print each plate twice.
Interlock the base and extension.
Optional to use spacers (~155mm long Internal space)
Optional, use glue or acetone to permanently join together.
Snap to the top of your Prusa Mendel.
Add a spool of your choosing.
Happy Printing.
